body:
I can't reproduce locally on pandas master with the same matplotlib.

Can you debug it any further?

On Mon, Jan 21, 2019 at 12:15 AM Kurt Peek <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible
>
> import randomimport dateutil.parserimport pandas as pdimport matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>
> start = dateutil.parser.parse("1 January 2019")
> end = dateutil.parser.parse("3 January 2019")
>
> data = [start + (end - start) * random.random() for _ in range(100)]
>
> df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=['Time'])
>
> hist = df.hist(column='Time')
> # df['Time'].hist()
>
> plt.show()
>
> Problem description
>
> When I try to run the code snippet above, I get the following error
> message:
>
> $ python3 pandas_histogram.py
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "pandas_histogram.py", line 13, in <module>
>     hist = df.hist(column='Time')
>   File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pandas/plotting/_core.py", line 2408, in hist_frame
>     layout=layout)
>   File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pandas/plotting/_tools.py", line 238, in _subplots
>     ax0 = fig.add_subplot(nrows, ncols, 1, **subplot_kw)
>   File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/matplotlib/figure.py", line 1367, in add_subplot
>     a = subplot_class_factory(projection_class)(self, *args, **kwargs)
>   File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/matplotlib/axes/_subplots.py", line 60, in __init__
>     ).format(maxn=rows*cols, num=num))
> ValueError: num must be 1 <= num <= 0, not 1
>
> Expected Output
>
> If I run df['Time'].hist() instead (the commented-out line in the
> snippet), it works fine and I see a histogram:
>
